content: The universal property of Kan extension along p:A→Bp:A\to Bp:A→B is normally given in terms of an adjunction between hom-categories [A,C](f,gp)≃[B,C](lanpf,g)A,C\simeq B,C[A,C](f,gp)≃[B,C](lanp​f,g). This requires fixing a codomain CCC -- is there a way to describe the "global" view, just in terms of the coslice 2-categories A/CatA/\mathrm{Cat}A/Cat and B/CatB/\mathrm{Cat}B/Cat?
Precomposition by ppp is a 2-functor −∘p:B/Cat→A/Cat-\circ p: B/\mathrm{Cat}\to A/\mathrm{Cat}−∘p:B/Cat→A/Cat. The question is whether left Kan extension along ppp defines a left 2-adjoint.

First we at least need functoriality. Suppose we have a morphism
(f,φ):(Y,h:A→Y)→(Z,k:A→Z)(f,\varphi):(Y, h:A\to Y)\to (Z,k:A\to Z)(f,φ):(Y,h:A→Y)→(Z,k:A→Z) in A/CatA/\mathrm{Cat}A/Cat.

What is lanp(f,φ):lanp(h)→lanp(k)lan_p(f,\varphi): lan_p(h)\to lan_p(k)lanp​(f,φ):lanp​(h)→lanp​(k) in B/CatB/\mathrm{Cat}B/Cat?

Maybe it's better seen from an indexed perspective...
For any 2-category we have a hom K(−,−):Kop×K→CatK(-,-):K^{op}\times K\to \mathrm{Cat}K(−,−):Kop×K→Cat.

Each K(p,−):K(b,−)→K(a,−)::K→CatK(p,-):K(b,-)\to K(a,-)::K\to \mathrm{Cat}K(p,−):K(b,−)→K(a,−)::K→Cat should have a left adjoint, which should induce an adjunction ∫K(a,−)≃a/K⇋b/K≃∫K(b,−)\int K(a,-)\simeq a/K \leftrightharpoons b/K \simeq \int K(b,-)∫K(a,−)≃a/K⇋b/K≃∫K(b,−). Hopefully.
I think it's right. I'll try to find some time to write it up and post it here.

The short story is that if KKK is co/complete, the embedding y:Kop→[K,Cat]y:K^{op}\to [K,Cat]y:Kop→[K,Cat] gives triple adjunctions and hence is of the form Kop→Adj(Adj([K,Cat]))K^{op}\to Adj(Adj([K,Cat]))Kop→Adj(Adj([K,Cat])). We can then compose that with the Grothendieck construction ∫:[K,Cat]→Cat\int: [K,Cat]\to Cat∫:[K,Cat]→Cat, to get

Kop→yAdj(Adj([K,Cat]))→A(A(∫))Adj(Adj(Cat))K^{op}\xrightarrow{y} Adj(Adj([K,Cat])) \xrightarrow{A(A(\int))} Adj(Adj(Cat))Kopy​Adj(Adj([K,Cat]))A(A(∫))​Adj(Adj(Cat))

which sends each p:a→bp:a\to bp:a→b to a triple adjunction a/K→Σp⊣Δp⊣Πpb/Ka/K \xrightarrow{\Sigma_p \dashv \Delta_p \dashv \Pi_p} b/Ka/KΣp​⊣Δp​⊣Πp​​b/K. We can glue these together to get a nice fibration over KKK, which might be something like an "internal language" of KKK.

One thing I was confused about is the difference between strict slice categories and lax ones... I haven't thought a whole lot about the 2-Yoneda embedding, but it seems like if you want to keep all the information, you need to consider Kop→[K,Cat]laxK^{op}\to [K,Cat]_{lax}Kop→[K,Cat]lax​, where each morphism in KopK^{op}Kop induces a lax 2-natural transformation rather than a strict one. That should give everything enough room to breathe.
If anyone knows good references for any of this, I'd appreciate it.

Christian Williams said:

you need to consider Kop→[K,Cat]laxK^{op}\to [K,Cat]_{lax}Kop→[K,Cat]lax​, where each morphism in KopK^{op}Kop induces a lax 2-natural transformation rather than a strict one.

Hm, sorry I don't think this makes sense. I'm just looking for a way to describe how ∫K(a,−)≃a//K\int K(a,-)\simeq a//K∫K(a,−)≃a//K (the lax slice 2-category) in the same way that ∫C(c,−)≃c/C\int C(c,-)\simeq c/C∫C(c,−)≃c/C for 1-categories. But K(a,−)K(a,-)K(a,−) goes to Cat\mathrm{Cat}Cat, not 2Cat2\mathrm{Cat}2Cat. So we need some extra information about the fact that KKK is more than just an indexed category, because it has 2-cells.

Here @Mike Shulman considers some subtleties - https://ncatlab.org/michaelshulman/show/slice+2-category - and takes the pseudo definition to be more fundamental than the lax one. Do you have thoughts about how to form either one as (the fibers of) a variant of the Grothendieck construction? If you're busy, no problem. Thanks.

(I guess that's a silly question, because we can just define the indexed 2-category Kop→2CatK^{op}\to 2\mathrm{Cat}Kop→2Cat which sends aaa to a//Ka//Ka//K. What I really mean to ask is how/whether a//Ka//Ka//K can be constructed from the representable K(a,−)K(a,-)K(a,−).)
Are you talking about slice categories or co-slice categories? Usually the notation a/ ⁣/Ka/\!/ Ka//K means a co-slice under aaa rather than a slice over aaa.
Sorry, yes I mean co-slice everywhere.

Well, the ordinary representable of a 1-category lands in Set, not Cat, but we can still do a Grothendieck construction by regarding sets as discrete categories. Have you tried the analogous thing with the embedding of Cat in 2-Cat?
Ah! I see, yes I think that should work.
Thanks.
Then we get a 2-∗\ast∗-bifibration over any co/complete 2-category KKK, with the fibers being lax coslices and the adjoints given by extensions. Do you know if anyone has thought about this?

Well, I don't think that co/completeness of KKK ensures that all left and right Kan extensions exist; for that you need ("internal") co/completeness of the codomain. I would also be surprised if Kan extensions are adjoints to composition in this sense; I would expect the left adjoint, in particular, to instead be some kind of pushout.

Oh, yes I was being loose with the term co/completeness... is there a sufficient condition on KKK for the existence of all extensions, or is that probably asking too much? And I'm curious about your second sentence. Is it not true that lanplan_planp​ can be understood (under certain conditions) as giving a left adjoint to −∘p:K(b,−)→K(a,−)-\circ p: K(b,-)\to K(a,-)−∘p:K(b,−)→K(a,−)?
Well, you can assume that "KKK has all extensions". But I don't know offhand of any 2-categories that do.

Certainly Lanp\mathrm{Lan}_pLanp​ is a left adjoint to −∘p:K(b,c)→K(a,c)-\circ p : K(b,c) \to K(a,c)−∘p:K(b,c)→K(a,c) for any fixed ccc that admits all ppp-extensions. But these adjoints don't generally vary naturally with ccc.

There are two different indexed categories here that I think may be being confused. On the one hand there is the indexed 2-category Kop→2CatK^{\mathrm{op}}\to 2CatKop→2Cat that sends aaa to a/ ⁣/Ka/\!/Ka//K. In that case, the left adjoint to precomposition should be some kind of pushout, and if all such exist it would be some kind of 2-bifibration (though I haven't thought about the laxness issues.)

On the other there is the co-indexed category K→CatK\to CatK→Cat that sends ccc to K(a,c)K(a,c)K(a,c) for some fixed aaa. In that case precomposition is not a restriction operation within one indexed category, but a map from one indexed category to another (i.e. a natural transformation), and in this case its adjoints should indeed be some kind of Kan extensions (insofar as they exist), although I think in general they will only form lax or colax transformations.

Mike Shulman said:

Certainly Lanp\mathrm{Lan}_pLanp​ is a left adjoint to −∘p:K(b,c)→K(a,c)-\circ p : K(b,c) \to K(a,c)−∘p:K(b,c)→K(a,c) for any fixed ccc that admits all ppp-extensions. But these adjoints don't generally vary naturally with ccc.

Okay, I see why now. But it's precisely the absolute extensions which do vary naturally in this way, right?

Mike Shulman said:

Well, you can assume that "KKK has all extensions". But I don't know offhand of any 2-categories that do.

Maybe the 2-category of co/complete categories and co/continuous functors? Or something similar.

As for your latter point, I see I was mixing two levels; I need to think more about this. But it seems to me that under the right conditions there should be a 2-fibration with adjoints given by extensions.

Well, I wasn't exactly mixed up. If you look at the composite above, I'm considering the embedding a↦K(a,−)a\mapsto K(a,-)a↦K(a,−). If we restrict to absolute extensions, then each −∘p:K(b,−)→K(a,−)-\circ p: K(b,-)\to K(a,-)−∘p:K(b,−)→K(a,−) has left and right adjoints, because they vary naturally with composition.

Then taking the 2-Grothendieck of those representables (after including Cat→2Cat\mathrm{Cat\to 2Cat}Cat→2Cat, as you say) we get a//Ka//Ka//K. So... somehow it seems like left extension is getting mapped to pushout? Something strange/interesting happens, unless I am indeed confused.

Yes, absolute extensions do vary naturally that way. But absolute extensions are pretty hard to come by; the usual pointwise Kan extensions constructed via limits and colimits are not in general absolute.

A cocomplete category as target admits all left Kan extensions along functors with small domain. But a cocomplete category itself is never small (unless it's a poset), so you can't get a 2-category admitting all Kan extensions that way unless you go down to something like complete lattices.

Yes. I thought that absolute extensions were the same as relative adjunctions, but now I see that those are absolute liftings. (Considering that relative monads are becoming more popular and applied, I was thinking there might be an interesting construction here.)
And yes, the conflict between completeness and size is constrictive.

The reason I'm interested is that extensions generalize dependent sum and product. If there were a 2-categorical version of the codomain hyperdoctrine, it would expand the scope of dependent type theory substantially.
I understand that there are significant conditions, obstacles, considerations; but I imagine there are ways it can work.
(I'm returning to your nLab pages about 2-topos theory, because I realize you've thought a lot about the internal logic of 2-categories.)

I think I'd need to see written out in more detail exactly what constructions you're intending to perform, and this isn't really the format. If you do write something up, feel free to share it by email.
